docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1856, just five years before the outbreak of the Civil War, the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company printed a pamphlet offering slave owners in six Southern states the option of insuring the lives of their slaves. For just $2, Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee residents, for example, could purchase a 12-month policy from the Hartford-based insurer on a 10-year-old domestic servant that would yield $100 if the slave died. Policies for older slaves, like a 45-year-old, were more expensive, costing the slave owner $5.50 a year.
docs.abstract: Article on recent interest in slave policies insurance companies, particularly in Connecticut and Rhode Island, offered to slave owners in southern states before Civil War; Deadria Farmer-Paellman filed lawsuit in March, seeking apology and reparations, against Aetna Inc, FleetBoston Financial Corp and CSX Corp, claiming they profited from slave trade; photos; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 9:15 in the morning, Dr. Jim Levine ducks out of Exam Room 6 while a medical assistant gives his patient an EKG. He goes to his office and sits at his computer to take notes on the possible case of strep sitting in Exam Room 3, a young woman wrapped in about 17 layers of clothes and still shivering. ''Grade II tonsils,'' he types, ''with exudate on right.'' Levine is 33, but in body type and energy he reminds you of a 14-year-old boy. His movements are quick and barely contained, and he walks faster than lots of people run. Before he leaves his office, Levine writes a prescription for the allergy medicine Allegra and prints a copy to give to the patient in Exam 6. Then he prints his report, punches holes in it, puts it in the patient's file and saves a version on his computer. He calls a pharmacy in Roxbury, fills out a specialist referral form for the Harvard Pilgrim plan and returns a call from a 56-year-old woman in Boxboro who has fallen and hit her head on the toilet. A complicated computer system allows the front desk to send phone messages to Levine's computer, where they wait in a queue like e-mail. The phone lines have been open for about 15 minutes, and he already has five messages waiting. When he gets off the phone with Roxbury, he ''walks'' back toward the exam rooms, where there are now three patients stripped to their skivvies, flipping through old issues of People.
docs.abstract: Devin Friedman article on Dr Jim Levine of Brookline, Mass, who is contemplating leaving his medical group, where he must see 24 patients a day, for 'concierge' practice in which he would see two or three; patients in concierge pratice pay $4,000 annual fee, which is separate from whatever they have to pay for office visits or house calls and regular insurance premiums paid by them and employer; Levine says he would not make switch for more money, but for freedom to practice kind of medicine he cannot under strictures of managed care and to spend more time with his family and on other interests; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate surged last month to 6 percent, its highest level in almost eight years, the government said yesterday in a sign that many companies are too worried about the economy to begin hiring again. The Labor Department's report raised the possibility that the current economic recovery could resemble the so-called jobless recovery of the early 1990's, when unemployment continued to rise for many months after a recession had ended. [Economic analysis, Page C1.]
docs.abstract: Labor Dept reports unemployment rate in April was 6 percent, highest in almost eight years; economists caution that jump in unemployment rate, from 5.7 percent, may have exaggerated economy's problems; companies added total of 41,000 jobs to their payrolls in April, but hiring of temporary workers is responsible for entire increase; technological advances are allowing businesses to increase production in recent months without adding permanent employees; many economists feel job market is showing tentative signs of turning around from recession; cite fact that manufacturers, hardest hit by downturn, cut 19,000 jobs in April, smallest reduction since late 2000; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The unemployment rate surged last month to 6 percent, its highest level in almost eight years, the government said yesterday in a sign that many companies are too worried about the economy to begin hiring again.    The Labor Department's report...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush is to be commended on his recent statement in support of mental health parity (news article, April 30). He joins the majority of Americans who now realize that mental illnesses are very real illnesses that are also quite common. Fortunately, they are also very treatable. We can now help most children, adolescents and adults who suffer from mental illnesses.
docs.abstract: Dr David Fassler letter commends Pres Bush for his recent statement in support of mental health parity (Apr 30 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans threatened to kill a trade bill being considered by the Senate after Democrats inserted a provision that would assist steelworkers who lost their health insurance when their employers went bankrupt. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, called the measure a ''bridge'' for the workers while Congress debated how to deal with the problem. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said he would use Senate rules to block the bill, which would grant President Bush more authority in negotiating trade deals, as long as it contained the steel provision. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Dispute Over Trade Bill

docs.abstract: Sen Phil Gramm threatens to kill bill giving Pres Bush more authority in negotiating trade deals after Senate Democrats insert provision that would assist steelworkers who lost their health insurance when their employers went bankrupt (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a private psychiatrist with about 45 percent of my patients on Medicaid or Medicare, I agree with Marc Siegel (Op-Ed, May 1) that Medicare should be expanded. But let's not stop with prescription drugs. The program should cover all Americans. We could change its name to National Health Insurance. Were this to happen, I'd gladly accept a pay cut. J. WESLEY BOYD, M.D. Northampton, Mass., May 2, 2002 The writer is a lecturer in religion at Smith College and in psychiatry at Harvard Medical School.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr J Wesley Boyd says he would gladly accept cut in Medicaid or Medicare reimbursement if all Ameriacns were covered under National Health Insurance0

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Toward Mental Health Parity'' (editorial, May 1): While President Bush should be applauded for his support of mental health parity, a large group of people suffering from chronic disease will continue to lack adequate coverage for the care they need even if the proposed legislation becomes law.
docs.abstract: Letter from Harvey Weiner sys May 1 editorial on mental health parity fails to mention that people addicted to drugs or alcohol are routinely discriminated against by health plans that deny access to adequate treatment

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Patients, Not Numbers'' (Op-Ed, May 1), Marc Siegel asks doctors to carry the burden of Medicare's problems. Yet doctors now face unlimited liability, reimbursements that have declined for 10 years, employees who require pay and benefits that match or exceed inflation and insurmountable paperwork.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Charles F Glassman calls for close look at disparity between doctors asked to carry burden of Medicare's problems and health insurance industry boasting huge profits (Marc Siegel May 1 Op-Ed)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years after riots burned through the inner city here, Los Angeles is marking the occasion with a cascade of speeches, and to a remarkable degree, the talk is rosy. Community leaders have congratulated themselves for restoring the cityscape with dozens of new shopping complexes, and for conducting multiethnic forums.

headline.main: Los Angeles Inner City Beset By Chronic Health Problems

docs.abstract: South Central Los Angeles, blighted community that has made economic strides since rioting of 1992, still has some of most widespread and chronic health problems in Los Angeles County, including crippling levels of diabetes, lung cancer, asthma, obesity and heart disease; situation is aggravated by fact that largely Latino immigrant population has highest number of uninsured people in county; budget problems are forcing county health department to reduce its budget sharply and possibly lay off staff members (M)
